etymologies: late 16th century. From southern + -ly, probably partly as alteration of southerly

definitions: Situated in or towards the south.
Of a wind: blowing from the south; = "southerly". Now somewhat rare.
Designating people inhabiting or originating from the southern part of a country or region.

etymologies: late 16th century; earliest use found in Thomas Blundeville (fl. 1561), author and translator. From southern + -ly, probably partly as alteration of southerly

definitions: In the south; towards the south, in a southerly direction.
